What you post on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and other social media platforms has never been more important. Especially, if you are planning to apply for the US visa. The US Secretary of State Marco Rubio has reportedly ordered diplomats overseas to scrutinize the social media content of some applicants for student and other types of visas. According to a report in The New York Times, quoting US government officials, the aim of scouring social media accounts of the US Visa applicants is an effort to bar those suspected of criticizing the United States and Israel from entering America.The US secretary of state reportedly laid out the instructions in a long Cable sent to diplomatic missions across the world on March 25. Rubio‚Äôs directive reportedly said that starting immediately, consular officers must refer certain student and exchange visitor visa applicants to the ‚Äúfraud prevention unit‚Äù for a ‚Äúmandatory social media check‚Äù. For those unaware, the fraud prevention unit of an embassy‚Äôs or consulate‚Äôs section for consular affairs helps screen applicants.The cable sent by Marco Rubio reportedly described the broad parameters that diplomats should use to judge whether an applicant needs to be denied a visa. It is said to specify a type of applicant whose social media posts should be scrutinized. These reportedly include: Someone who is suspected of having terrorist ties or sympathies; who had a student or exchange visa between October 7, 2023, and August 31, 2024; or who has had a visa terminated since that October date.The dates specified by Marco Rubio in the Cable are said to indicate that one of the main aims of the social media searches is to reject the applications of international students who have expressed sympathy for Palestinians during the war.The Cable further states that the applicants can be denied a visa if their behavior or actions show they bear ‚Äúa hostile attitude toward U.S. citizens or U.S. culture (including government, institutions, or founding principles).‚ÄùThe requested visa types that would set off extra scrutiny as per the Cable are reported to be: F, M and J, which is student and exchange visitor visas. The spokesperson made the comment replying to a question from The New York Times about whether the department was using artificial intelligence to scan databases and social media posts to find visa holders to decide those whose visa should be revoked.

Article Title: Bryan Johnson says he has quit a drug popular in anti-ageing circles after it actually accelerated his aging process
Article Text:
(Pic courtesy: Youtube/ Bryan johnson)

The drug that Bryan Johnson says accelerated his aging process

Anti-aging influencer Bryan Johnson , known for his extreme $2 million annual health regimen aimed at reversing aging, has publicly admitted that a key component of his protocol, the drug Rapamycin, may have been detrimental to his health. In a recent YouTube video, the 46-year-old biohacker revealed he experienced several negative side effects after five years of carefully adjusting his Rapamycin dosage.The immunosuppressant, initially developed for organ transplant recipients, gained popularity in anti-aging circles due to studies suggesting it could extend lifespan by targeting the mTOR pathway. Johnson was inspired by research showing increased lifespan in mice and improved health outcomes in a human trial.However, instead of the anticipated rejuvenation, Johnson suffered from mouth ulcers, slow-healing wounds, elevated cholesterol, and blood glucose spikes. Most concerning was a sustained increase in his resting heart rate, a crucial metric for his recovery and sleep quality. These physiological changes prompted him to discontinue the drug.Adding to his concerns, a recent Yale University study challenged the purported anti-aging benefits of Rapamycin, suggesting it might actually accelerate biological aging by negatively impacting epigenetic markers.Despite the setback, Johnson stated that stopping Rapamycin was a "reset," not a surrender, emphasizing the importance of sharing both successes and failures in the pursuit of understanding how to slow aging. He acknowledged the irony of a central element of his meticulously planned regimen potentially causing harm, stating, "To those of you laughing at home, I‚Äôm laughing with you." Johnson maintains that his approach is part of a scientific exploration, accepting the risks involved in trying to identify interventions that genuinely impact the aging process.
Article Summary: Bryan Johnson, known for his extreme $2 million annual health regimen aimed at reversing aging, has publicly admitted that a key component of his protocol, the drug Rapamycin, may have been detrimental to his health. Article Title: Walmart Boycott: World's largest retailer tells protesters, 'we are America's ...'

Walmart, however, emphasised its dedication to supporting local charities, disaster response, hunger relief, workforce development, and conservation efforts.A report from SuperMarketNews, citing data from Numerator, suggests that Walmart may be more resistant to boycotts compared to other retailers. Article Title: USCIS' 'plain and straight message' to H1-B, Green Card and other visa applicants: There are only two...

The US Citizenship and Immigration Services ( USCIS ) has updated its policy to clarify that it will only recognize two biological sexes‚Äîmale and female. Proper management of our immigration system is a matter of national security, not a place to promote and coddle an ideology that permanently harms children and robs real women of their dignity, safety, and well-being.‚ÄùUnder the new guidance, a person‚Äôs sex will be determined based on the birth certificate issued at or closest to the time of birth. ‚ÄúIf the birth certificate issued at or nearest to the time of birth indicates a sex other than male or female, USCIS will base the determination of sex on secondary evidence. See Volume 1, General Policies and Procedures, Part E, Adjudications, Chapter 6, Evidence, Section B, Primary and Secondary Evidence [1 USCIS-PM E.6(B)],‚Äù the agency stated.The agency further added that the benefits will not be denied solely based on how someone identifies their sex, it also confirmed that it does not issue documents with a blank sex field or one that differs from the original birth certificate. Article Title: Government testing new Aadhaar app: No physical card and photocopies; how it will change how you use Aadhaar card

Article Title: Apple, tech sector get relief: Smartphones, laptops excluded and other key electronics exempted from Trump Tariffs
Article Text:
Phones, PCs, chips exempted from Trump‚Äôs reciprocal tariffs

The US Customs and Border Protection has released new guidelines that specify certain technology devices and components will be exempt from reciprocal tariffs initiated by US President Donald Trump . The latest notice comes as previous action had raised significant concerns for technology companies, most notably Apple , which manufactures the majority of its iPhones and other products within China.According to a report by CNBC, the information was disseminated late Friday (April 11) evening. The latest guidance is a direct response to President Trump's earlier decision to impose a 145% tariff on products originating from China.The newly-issued tariff guidance identifies a range of electronics that will receive exclusions. This list includes laptops, semiconductors, solar cells, flat panel television displays, flash drives, memory cards, and solid-state drives, all of which are used for data storage.Notably, these products may be subject to future duties. These exemptions represent a somewhat favourable outcome for technology companies such as Apple. As per data from Evercore ISI, Apple manufactures over 80% of its products in China, including 80% of iPads and more than half of its Mac computers.Recently, Apple experienced a loss of over $640 billion in market value in the period following President Trump's tariff announcement.Moreover, Apple reportedly chartered multiple cargo flights to ship an estimated 1.5 million iPhones, weighing approximately 600 tons, from India to the US. This move aimed at ramping up inventory in the home country to mitigate the potential impact of tariffs previously threatened by Trump.
Article Summary: US Customs and Border Protection has released new guidelines that specify certain technology devices and components will be exempt from reciprocal tariffs initiated by US President Donald Trump. This list includes laptops, semiconductors, solar cells, flat panel television displays, flash drives, memory cards, and solid-state drives.

Article Title: Donald Trump just gave Samsung a 'huge problem' and it is called Vietnam
Article Text:
Vietnam's role in Samsung's operations

Impact on Samsung and Vietnam

US President Donald Trump's latest tariff hikes have created a significant challenge for Samsung Electronics, with Vietnam emerging as a focal point of the escalating trade tensions. The new tariffs, which raise duties on Vietnamese exports to the US to 46%, threaten to disrupt Samsung's global supply chain and its reliance on Vietnam as a manufacturing hub.Vietnam has been a cornerstone of Samsung's manufacturing strategy since the South Korean tech giant entered the country in 1989. The company produces 60% of its global smartphone output in Vietnam, with many of these devices destined for the US, where Samsung is the second-largest smartphone vendor. Vietnam's $120 billion trade surplus with the US has now placed it squarely in the crosshairs of Trump's tariff policies.The tariff hike has exposed vulnerabilities in Vietnam's export-driven economy and Samsung's heavy reliance on the country. While Vietnam has secured a temporary reprieve with a 90-day pause on the full tariff implementation, the uncertainty has already prompted Samsung and its suppliers to explore alternative production strategies. Options include increasing output in India or South Korea, though these shifts would be costly and time-consuming.The tariffs not only jeopardize Samsung's operations but also highlight the risks of over-reliance on a single manufacturing base. Vietnam, which has benefited from companies diversifying away from China, now faces challenges such as rising labor costs, power supply issues, and the loss of earlier tax incentives.
Article Summary: Vietnam has been a cornerstone of Samsung's manufacturing strategy since 1989. Samsung produces 60% of its global smartphone output in Vietnam, with many of these devices destined for the US. Vietnam's $120 billion trade surplus with the US has now placed it squarely in the crosshairs of Trump's tariff policies.
